Award.AwardTitle: Attracting and Retaining Promising Transfer Students into STEM Fields

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The effort of the college to open access to transfer students comes at a time when increasingly sophisticated methodological methods are being developed to forge connections across science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. This project acts as a catalyst for these developments and offers up to 20 transfer students a pathway to achieve bachelor degrees. This project is motivated by the institutional objective to better attract and retain science concentrators in STEM fields. Additionally, a core team of faculty, whose work investigates questions in computational science, artificial intelligence, and the biological sciences, are interested in building structural and cultural cohesion around concentrators who may already be motivated by work and life experiences to excel in STEM fields.

Intellectual Merit: While the college has done well attracting underrepresented students in STEM fields, the overall attrition rate for underrepresented groups is somewhat high. The college has begun to take deliberate and careful measures to address these attrition rates. This project allows the college to offer a more robust financial aid package to help to attract and retain transfer students. These transfer students provide diversification, which strengthens the overall demographic makeup of the college and offers a more diverse range of perspectives in the classroom.

Broader Impact: The inquiry-driven, cross-disciplinary approach to teaching science at the college has demonstrated success in attracting students from diverse backgrounds to STEM fields. According to recent admissions data, the college graduates more science concentrators (15%) than it initially attracts (10%). Moreover, from 2005-08, women and students from underrepresented groups comprised 70% of science concentrators. Many of these students enter a range of scientific and medical careers, or pursue graduate study upon matriculating. This project allows faculty to work with a greater number of students and is expected to result in higher numbers of talented graduates prepared to make meaningful contributions to national and international scientific challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
End-of-program Statistics

After a six year program, a total of 18 students received funds to pursue studies in the sciences. Of these, 13 completed their bachelor degrees, two are on track to finish by the end of the spring 2018 semester, and three left the college before completing their degrees. This compares very positively to the situation before the program began, when there were no students transferring from community colleges in the sciences.

Current professional occupations of graduated students

Of the 13 students that have graduated from the program, we have received information regarding professional whereabouts from eight of them. One graduate is working in a private science laboratory, assisting with research in neuroscience. One is working at an undergraduate academic institution assisting with science grants management. Five students are working in the environmental sciences and environmental education field, and one is working with a non-profit organization that advocates for citizens’ digital rights in the information age.

Lessons learned

Effect of scholarships in ability to afford the cost of college

All students interviewed volunteered that the cost of attending Hampshire would have been prohibitive without their NSF STEM Grants. Some of the program graduates mentioned that, without a doubt, they would not have been able to afford tuition, room, and board. For two students, though, even a $10,000/year scholarship was not enough to cover their financial aid needs, needing to leave the program before obtaining a degree because of economic hardship.

Factors leading to degree completion

Students mentioned that the single most important factor to their academic success and academic satisfaction was the level of contact and support they received from their academic advisors. The first moment this became important was immediately after they entered the institution, given the fact that they were all transfer students. This meant they did not receive the same level of orientation to our campus and our academic program as students that started at Hampshire straight out of high school. Contact with their academic advisors also became most important during their final, Division III year, when students concentrate on working on a year-long independent project.

Recruitment

On those admission cycles when our admissions unit was able to pay particular attention to our local community colleges, there was a noticeable difference in enrollment from them. For example, the cohort during the program’s first year included two students from a local community college that ended up completing studies in environmental sciences. In other years,oOur admissions office, and in particular the admission counselor working with transfer students, put particular attention on recruiting students from Holyoke Community College (HCC), from where we had had some, but not many, transfer students into the STEM Grant program. The counselor visited HCC during the academic year, and also organized for students interested in the program to visit our campus. During their visit, these students attended specialized meetings with our financial aid officers, and had lunch with current Hampshire students, the Dean for Multicultural Education, and myself. More than half of the students that attended this visit applied and were admitted for admissions at Hampshire.

Effects of a Hampshire Education

Students mentioned that Hampshire provided them with the opportunity to develop important professional skills, such as critical thinking, the ability to work both independently and in groups, time management, statistical analysis, computer modeling, and general organizational skills. At the same time, graduates reported they wished they had received more instruction on what their upcoming job search process was likely to be like.

Possible gender bias

It is of note that the five students that have not completed their degree as the program concludes are all female. Two of them, though, are on track to finish their degrees by the end of the spring 2018 semester, and are “on track” to finish on time based on the number of credits that they transferred in with. One of the other three students not to complete reported financial hardship beyond what was solved with a SSTEM Grant. Another one of these five female students was on track to finish her degree, but opted for a lifestyle change, joining a cooperative agricultural organization in France. All these cases, taken together, raise the possibility of particular interventions being needed for this specific student population. At the same time, of the 13 students that finished their degrees, six are female.
Dissemination efforts

Results and findings from this program have so far been shared internally with the Dean of Faculty and Vice President for Academic Affairs, the Dean for Multicultural Education and Inclusion, the Chief Diversity Officer, and the Deans of the schools of Natural Science and of Cognitive Science. Externally, results have been shared with both science faculty and academic advisors within the Five College consortium.
